paragraphs.name: 79f9
paragraphs.text: Consciously co-creating the future

paragraphs.name: f0d6
paragraphs.text: “The future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams.”
— Eleanor Roosevelt

paragraphs.name: ae16
paragraphs.text: Once we understand that we live in a world where everything is connected to everything else, where small actions can have far reaching consequences, where — every day — we cannot but affect the future of all life on earth by the way we live our lives today, once we have understood this powerful reality of interconnectedness and interdependence as a fundamental property of an expanding, transforming and evolving universe, we become conscious of our own power and responsibility to co-design and co-create a healthier, more just and regenerative future for all.

paragraphs.name: 746a
paragraphs.text: It is in fact impossible to live your life and not affect the future of all there is in some way or another. This is the nature of interconnectedness, whether we are conscious or unaware of our co-creative agency as participants in and part of natural process.

paragraphs.name: e9cd
paragraphs.text: This awareness of our co-creative agency in this word is based on a shift in worldview, from the mechanistic, reductionist paradigm of the “objective” observer to the organismic, holistic paradigm of the subjective participant.

paragraphs.name: 81bc
paragraphs.text: This shift in worldview corresponds to the shift in cultural dominance from the story of separation to the story of interbeing. While the former can make us feel like a helpless ‘cog in a big machine’ unable to affect anything in the big ‘system’ out there, the latter returns to us the co-creative power and responsibility that is our birthright as participants and expressions of a living, conscious and creative universe.

paragraphs.name: bb24
paragraphs.text: “Carefully watch your thoughts, for they become your words. Manage and watch your words, for they will become your actions. Consider and judge your actions, for they become your habits. Acknowledge and watch your habits, for they shall become your values. Understand and embrace your values, for they become your destiny.”

paragraphs.name: a444
paragraphs.text: — Mahatma Gandhi

paragraphs.name: b621
paragraphs.text: Socially and ecologically engaged evolutionary activism is one way of following Gandhi’s advice to “be the change you want to see in the world.” As we engage consciously with our power and responsibility to co-create the world we would like to see, we connect with our individual potential to affect small and large-scale changes, and at the same time we are reminded to be humble and acknowledge the power of collaboration and cooperation.

paragraphs.name: 5a1a
paragraphs.text: History shows that individuals can change the world, but its also shows that groups of individuals can do so even better. As the old African proverb says:

paragraphs.name: 7ce7
paragraphs.text: “Alone you may go faster, but together we will go further.”

paragraphs.name: 42ba
paragraphs.text: In living the life of a socially and ecologically engaged evolutionary activist, it is very important to be patient, compassionate, and resilient, not only in dealing with others, but also in our attitude towards ourselves. We need do nurture and draw on both inner and outer resilience on the path that now lies ahead of very aware and awake human being.

paragraphs.name: f938
paragraphs.text: The future of life is hanging by the frailest of threads — as anthropogenic climate change and the impact of centuries and millennia of degenerative human impact on the planet’s life-support-systems have pushed us into a mass extinction that might also spell the end of our own species.

paragraphs.name: 106d
paragraphs.text: An twelve hundred year old Buddhist prophecy speaks of this time we now find ourselves in. I first heard this prophecy from one of the most important teachers and mentors I have had on my path as a pilgrim and apprentice in service to the Earth and her people. Joanna Macy tells how she received this ‘Shambhala Prophecy’ from her teacher like this:

paragraphs.name: b26b
paragraphs.text: “There comes a time when all life on Earth is in danger. Barbarian powers have arisen. Although they waste their wealth in preparations to annihilate each other, they have much in common: weapons of unfathomable devastation and technologies that lay waste the world. It is now, when the future of all beings hangs by the frailest of threads, that the kingdom of Shambhala emerges.

paragraphs.name: c52f
paragraphs.text: You cannot go there, for it is not a place. It exists in the hearts and minds of the Shambhala warriors. But you cannot recognize a Shambhala warrior by sight, for there is no uniform or insignia, there are no banners. And there are no barricades from which to threaten the enemy, for the Shambhala warriors have no land of their own. Always they move on the terrain of the barbarians themselves.

paragraphs.name: d79d
paragraphs.text: Now comes the time when great courage is required of the Shambhala warriors, moral and physical courage. For they must go into the very heart of the barbarian power and dismantle the weapons. To remove these weapons, in every sense of the word, they must go into the corridors of power where the decisions are made.

paragraphs.name: 370c
paragraphs.text: The Shambhala warriors know they can do this because the weapons are manomaya, mind-made. This is very important to remember, Joanna. These weapons are made by the human mind. So they can be unmade by the human mind! The Shambhala warriors know that the dangers that threaten life on Earth do not come from evil deities or extraterrestrial powers. They arise from our own choices and relationships. So, now, the Shambhala warriors must go into training.

paragraphs.name: 795a
paragraphs.text: How do they train? I asked.
They train in the use of two weapons.

paragraphs.name: 65c0
paragraphs.text: The weapons are compassion and insight. Both are necessary. We need this first one,” he said, lifting his right hand, “because it provides us the fuel, it moves us out to act on behalf of other beings. But by itself it can burn us out. So we need the second as well, which is insight into the dependent co-arising of all things. It lets us see that the battle is not between good people and bad people, for the line between good and evil runs through every human heart. We realize that we are interconnected, as in a web, and that each act with pure motivation affects the entire web, bringing consequences we cannot measure or even see.

paragraphs.name: d775
paragraphs.text: But insight alone, he said, can seem too cool to keep us going. So we need as well the heat of compassion, our openness to the world’s pain. Both weapons or tools are necessary to the Shambhala warrior.”

paragraphs.name: 9aae
paragraphs.text: — Joanna Macy

paragraphs.name: f836
paragraphs.text: Do yourself the favour and listen to Joanna retelling how she received this prophesy herself many years ago in the video below. As you do, ask yourself:

paragraphs.name: 108f
paragraphs.text: Am I feeling called to rise up for life in this time of crisis and transformation?

paragraphs.name: f6ef
paragraphs.text: Am I ready to join the ranks of the Shambhala Warriors around the world?

paragraphs.name: 14c4
paragraphs.text: Am I ready to take responsibility for the way I co-create the future of life on Earth everyday with what I do or don’t do?
